Award.AwardTitle: Delineating the Roles of Dynamin-Related Proteins DRP2A and DRP2B in Regulating Plant Innate Immune Responses against Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
Higher organisms have developed effective mechanisms to protect themselves against microbial infection. Host defense responses must be tightly regulated: if hosts are unable to induce defenses, microbes take hold of them. If responses are continuously activated, host cells divert valuable resources from growth to defense resulting in host growth penalty. Some eukaryotic cells use ligand-induced endocytosis as a means for down-regulating receptor concentration from the cell surface to desensitize cells to stimuli and attenuate signaling responses. In this project, the investigator uses the FLS2/flagellin system to delineate roles of endocytosis in regulating immunity against bacteria. FLAGELLIN SENSITIVE 2 (FLS2) is the plant cell surface receptor that perceives bacterial flagellin to initiate defense signaling. FLS2 is the only plant immune receptor known to undergo ligand-induced endocytosis. Roles of FLS2 endocytosis in regulating responses and immunity, however, remain unknown. The investigator has identified the vesicular trafficking proteins Dynamin-Related Protein DRP2A and DRP2B as novel positive regulators of basal resistance against the bacteria Pseudomonas syringae. In this project, the investigator uses a combination of biochemical, live-cell imaging, proteomics, pathology and genetics approaches to address roles of DRP2s in regulating defense signaling, FLS2 endocytosis and immunity against bacteria.

In addition to enhancing the knowledge of DRP2 functions in cellular processes, this project could lead to novel strategies for enhancing innate immunity in plants and contributing to improved food, fiber, and biofuel production. The project also provides training opportunities for a postdoctoral researcher, graduate and undergraduate students. Furthermore, the investigator's group participates in outreach efforts by developing and presenting hands-on biological experiments to K-5 elementary school students. Undergraduate and elementary students will learn to gather, analyze, and interpret data. Society will profit from scientifically literate citizens with intellectual background crucial in making educated decisions about applications for science in their everyday lives.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Plants serve as crucial food sources for humans and provide non-food products including medicines, biofuel, wood and textiles. Similar to humans and other animals, plants have effective mechanisms to protect themselves against pathogens; but if a host is unable to induce defenses, a pathogen may invade and colonize the host. Plant diseases caused by microbial pathogens can severely reduce crop yield and nutritional quality and affect the aesthetic value of landscape plants and home gardens. As such, plant infection can result in direct economic losses reaching billions of dollars annually. Such loss can be devastating to individual farmers and entire nations. Thus, understanding how plants defend themselves is essential to protecting food supplies in the US and around the world. One approach to crop pathogen management is to develop highly disease-resistant crops. An important aspect of engineering durable crop pathogen resistance is elucidating and manipulating resistance pathways in model organisms.

The PI used the model plant Arabidopsis thaliana to identify and characterize novel components involved in the regulation of defense responses against the bacterial pathogen Pseudomonas syringae. Here, the PI focused on cellular components, named vesicle trafficking components, which help defense proteins, such as the plant receptor Flagellin Sensing 2 (FLS2), to travel to their place of function within a plant cell. The PI showed that FLS2 must be localized to the cell surface at the right time and in the right abundance in order to recognize the bacterial pathogen and initiate effective defense responses.

Furthermore, the PI used a combination of genetic and pharmacological tools to show that plant defenses induced by bacteria consist of a network of immune responses, which is made up out of at least three different branches, rather than a single, linear immune pathway. In particular, one of these branches emerged as critical for immunity against bacterial infection. This discovery is important, as it will allow targeting future efforts in boosting plant immunity against bacterial pathogen infection by specifically improving this branch of the plant defense pathway. Data and tools generated from this work will allow formulating new testable hypotheses on improving agricultural sustainability in the future.

This project also directly contributed in training two Ph.D. students, two undergraduate students and one postdoctoral fellow in state-of-the-art interdisciplinary techniques ranging from cell biology, molecular biology, plant physiology and biochemistry. In addition, the PI’s lab developed and shared outreach projects using authentic plant research for the general public and K-8 school students. Students at all levels will benefit from exposure to authentic science through student-driven research to develop critical thinking. Society will profit from scientifically literate citizens with intellectual background crucial in making educated decisions about applications for science in their everyday lives.
